newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia's YUKOS oil firm sees its 1997 output down.
newsitem.headline: Russia's YUKOS oil firm sees its 1997 output down.

text.p: Russia's third-largest oil company, NK YUKOS, said on Friday that its 1997 crude output would fall 6.8 percent from 1996 to 32.6 million tonnes.
Its Yuganskneftegaz production unit would see output slip next year to 24.6 million tonnes from this year's 26.37 million tonnes.
YUKOS said it planned an extraordinary shareholders' meeting for February 19, 1997 in Moscow, but did not say what issues would be discussed.
Oil output at YUKOS's Samaraneftegaz unit would slip to 8.0 million tonnes from 8.62 million in 1996.

The figures may augur ill for hopes of recovery in Russia's oil sector, where producers are struggling to recover from nearly a decade of steep declines that have nearly halved the country's oil output since its 1987 peak.

The statement said YUKOS planned to ship 63.5 percent of its 1997 output, or 20.56 million tonnes, to domestic refineries for processing. Exports would total 11.8 million tonnes and YUKOS valued receipts from this at $1.23 billion.
It did not say how it had estimated average world oil prices for 1997 to arrive at this figure.
The company gave no absolute figures for 1996 exports.
YUKOS said it would boost its refining operations this year by 13.6 percent from 1995 and process 18.46 million tonnes of crude.
Refining operations would rise 17.3 percent in 1997 to 21.66 million tonnes, with total oil products output at 17.27 million tonnes.
Oil product exports would total 3.78 million tonnes and YUKOS valued them at $446 million.
YUKOS is one of Russia's dozen or so vertically integrated oil companies.
